answer_html: Well, sure enough, if one always choses x = w + 1, then clearly it is always going to be larger than the w that was picked in the first place.
answer_latex:
\begin{description}\item Well, sure
enough, if one always choses \emph{x} = \emph{w} + 1, then clearly it is
always going to be larger than the \emph{w} that was picked in the first
place.
\end{description}
hints_html:
Try reformulating these two statements into more readable English.

The first statement is equivalent to

Given any real number, there exists a real number larger than that one.

The second statement is equivalent to

There exists a real number y that is strictly smaller than any real number.
hints_latex: Try reformulating these two statements into more readable English.
hints_raw:
Try reformulating these two statements into more readable English.
The first statement is equivalent to
:''Given any real number, there exists a real number larger than that one.''
The second statement is equivalent to
:''There exists a real number '''y''' that is strictly smaller than any real number.''
sols_html:
The second statement should appear wrong fairly immediately since it talking about the existence of the smallest real number which cannot exist. Let’s prove this:

The statement says that for any real number z it should be true that y < z, but if I pick z to be exactly that mysterious number y I should have y < y which is clearly impossible, so the statement is false.

Now we can prove that the first statement is true:

That statement says that if any real number w is picked, then one can find a real number x that is larger than w. Well, sure enough, if one always choses x = w + 1, then clearly it is always going to be larger than the w that was picked in the first place.
sols_latex:
The second statement should appear wrong fairly immediately since it
talking about the existence of \emph{the smallest real number} which
cannot exist. Let's prove this:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
The statement says that for \emph{any} real number \emph{z} it should be
true that \emph{y} \textless{} \emph{z}, but if I pick \emph{z} to be
exactly that mysterious number \emph{y} I should have \emph{y}
\textless{} \emph{y} which is clearly impossible, so the statement is
false.
\end{description}

Now we can prove that the first statement is true:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
That statement says that if any real number \emph{w} is picked, then one
can find a real number \emph{x} that is larger than \emph{w}. Well, sure
enough, if one always choses \emph{x} = \emph{w} + 1, then clearly it is
always going to be larger than the \emph{w} that was picked in the first
place.
\end{description}
sols_raw:
The second statement should appear wrong fairly immediately since it talking about the existence of ''the smallest real number'' which cannot exist. Let's prove this:

:The statement says that for ''any'' real number ''z'' it should be true that ''y'' < ''z'', but if I pick ''z'' to be exactly that mysterious number ''y'' I should have ''y'' < ''y'' which is clearly impossible, so the statement is false.

Now we can prove that the first statement is true:

:That statement says that if any real number ''w'' is picked, then one can find a real number ''x'' that is larger than ''w''. Well, sure enough, if one always choses ''x'' = ''w'' + 1, then clearly it is always going to be larger than the ''w'' that was picked in the first place.
statement_html:
Consider the following two statements:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{(a)} \text{ for all } w \in \mathbb{R}, \text{ there exists } x \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that } w < x.\end{aligned}\]

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{(b)} \text{ there exists } y \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that for all } z \in \mathbb{R} \text{, } y < z.\end{aligned}\]

One of the statement is true, and the other is false. Determine which is which. For the true one, prove that it is true; for the false one, prove that it is false.
statement_raw:
Consider the following two statements:
:<math>\mathbf{(a)} \text{ for all } w \in \mathbb{R}, \text{ there exists } x \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that } w < x.</math>
:<math>\mathbf{(b)} \text{ there exists } y \in \mathbb{R} \text{ such that for all } z \in \mathbb{R} \text{, } y < z.</math>
One of the statement is true, and the other is false. Determine which is which. For the true one, prove that it is true; for the false one, prove that it is false.
